author: James Allen
title: Albany JCC hosting World Series of Poker qualifier Sunday
text:
Albany
The 2015 World Series of Poker Main Event final table — a $10,000 buy-in event — is set for Nov. 9 at the Rio in Las Vegas. For fans of Texas Hold 'Em, it's the Super Bowl of poker.
On Sunday at the Albany Jewish Community Center , a charity event will provide one player the chance to compete next year's Main Event.
The Mohawk Honda World Series of Poker Main Event seat qualifier starts at 1 p.m. Sunday and offers local players a chance to check off a bucket-list item — and help out a good cause at the same time.
"Mohawk Honda has underwritten the main prize, and we are very thankful to them," Albany JCC Executive Director Adam Chaskin said.
"Primarily, the money will be going to our after-school programs and the early-childhood programs. The major portion of the money will be going toward our new program that takes on childhood obesity issues."
Chaskin said he began to think about the event after seeing something five years ago called the Kosher Poker Tour.
More Information
MOHAWK HONDA WSOP MAIN EVENT SEAT QUALIFIER
Where: Albany Jewish Community Center (340 Whitehall Road, Albany)
When: 1 p.m. Sunday
Entry fee: $200 (cash or credit card)
Starting chip stack: $5,000
"We wanted to target different people than we normally do when we conduct fund-raisers, where he ask them to come to a dinner," Chaskin said. "I talked to a couple of different JCCs that have held poker tournaments and thought, 'Why don't we try this?' We hired a professional company out of New Jersey to run the tournament. I want to make sure we do it right."
So far, there are more than 100 players registered, Chaskin said. Players can register online at albanyjcc.org or simply enter on site Sunday. The entrance fee is $200.
The blind structure will begin at $50-$100 and increase every 20 minutes. There also will be three re-buy opportunities during the first 100 minutes ($100 each) for the starting stack of $5,000 chips, plus one add-on. The re-buys are restricted to people low on chips.
In addition to the $10,000 WSOP Main Event seat, non-cash prizes will be awarded to players advancing to the final table.
For the players planning to enter who do not have extensive poker experience, there will be a poker tutorial beginning at 11:30 a.m.
Food will be available, and there are big-screen TVs near the tables so players can keep updated on Sunday's NFL games.
